However, the competition results were not changed and the title was left vacant rather than moving all the other competitors up one position.{{cite news |title=U.S. Title Is Taken Back From Harding |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=New York Times|date=July 1, 1994 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/07/01/sports/figure-skating-us-title-is-taken-back-from-harding.html |accessdate=2010-09-28}} == Attack on Nancy Kerrigan and aftermath == On {{start date|1994|1|6}}, one day before the [[1994 United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. Figure Skating Championship]] first Ladies' Singles competition, [[Nancy Kerrigan]] was attacked after a practice session at the Detroit [[Cobo Center|Cobo Arena]]. The assailant was Shane Stant, contracted to break her right leg. Stant and his uncle, Derrick Smith, were hired for this [[assault]] by Harding's ex-husband, Jeff Gillooly, and her one-time bodyguard, Shawn Eckardt.[https://sportsworld.nbcsports.com/nancy-tonya/]. ''NBC SportsWorld''. ''Nancy & Tonya'' (2014) documentary. Tonya telling a reporter "Shawn is my bodyguard" while he walks beside her on January 10, 1994 - time code ca 0:29:14 After failing to find Kerrigan at her Massachusetts training rink, Stant had taken a 20-hour bus trip to Detroit.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/23/sports/figure-skating-traveling-far-and-lying-low-to-get-nancy-kerrigan.html|title=Traveling Far and Lying Low to Get Nancy Kerrigan|work=New York Times|first=Joseph B. |last=Treaster|date=Jan 23, 1994|accessdate=2018-07-09}} Nancy Kerrigan was walking behind a curtain to a corridor when Stant rushed behind her. Using both hands, he then swung a 21-inch [[ASP, Inc.|ASP]] [[telescopic baton]] at her right leg, striking her above the knee. The intent was preventing her competing in both the National Championships (Kerrigan was the defending [[1993 U.S. Figure Skating Championships|1993 U.S. Ladies' Champion]]) and the Winter Olympics. Kerrigan's leg was not broken but severely bruised, forcing her to withdraw from the Championships and forgo competing to retain the U.S. Ladies' title.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/07/sports/figure-skating-kerrigan-attacked-after-practice-assailant-flees.html|title=Kerrigan Attacked After Practice; Assailant Flees |work=New York Times|first=Jere|last=Longman|date=Jan 7, 1994|accessdate=2018-07-11}} On January 8, Harding won the U.S. Ladies' Singles title; she and Kerrigan were then both selected for the [[United States at the 1994 Winter Olympics|1994 Olympic team]]. On February 1, Gillooly's attorney negotiated a [[plea bargain]] in exchange for testimony regarding all involved parties in the attack. He was sentenced in July after publicly apologizing to Kerrigan – even though, he said, "any apology coming from me rings hollow."{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-02-02/news/mn-18226_1_2-year-prison-term|title=Ex-Spouse Pleads Guilty & Implicates Harding|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|first=John|last=Balzar|date=Feb 2, 1994|access-date=2018-07-07}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/07/14/sports/figure-skating-gillooly-sentenced-to-2-years-in-jail.html|title=Gillooly Sentenced to 2 Years in Jail|newspaper=New York Times|agency=Associated Press|date=July 14, 1994|access-date=July 24, 2018}} Gillooly and Eckardt pleaded guilty to [[Racket (crime)|racketeering]], Stant and Smith (who drove Stant in the [[Crime scene getaway|getaway car]] and funneled money) pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit second-degree assault — all served prison time.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/05/17/sports/figure-skating-kerrigan-attacker-and-accomplice-sent-to-jail.html |title=Kerrigan Attacker & Accomplice Sent to Jail |newspaper=New York Times|date=May 17, 1994 |access-date=2016-11-28}}{{cite news |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/tonya-harding/2014/01/tonya_harding-nancy_kerrigan_2.html|title=20 years later: highlights in a timeline|last=Muldoon |first=Katy|date=Jan 6, 2014|newspaper=The Oregonian|accessdate=2018-06-25}} Judge Donald Londer noted the attack could have injured Kerrigan more seriously.{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1994/07/13/Gillooly-sentenced-in-Kerrigan-attack/5068774072000|title=Gillooly sentenced in Kerrigan attack|newspaper=United Press International (UPI)|date=July 13, 1994|access-date=2018-07-24}} On February 25, Harding finished eighth in the Olympics; Nancy Kerrigan, having recovered from her injury, won the [[Olympic medal|Olympic silver medal]] behind Oksana Baiul from [[Ukraine]]. Eckardt was released from prison in September 1995 and changed his name to Brian Sean Griffith; he died at age 40 on December 12, 2007.{{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20071215/ap_on_re_us/obit_griffith |title=Player in attack on Kerrigan dies at 40 |website=Yahoo News |date=Dec 15, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071218172722/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20071215/ap_on_re_us/obit_griffith |archivedate=Dec 18, 2007 |deadurl=yes}} [[File:Tonya Harding Olympic practice at Clackamas Town Center 1994 3.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1|Harding's practice sessions at [[Clackamas Town Center]], in preparation for the 1994 Winter Olympics, were attended by thousands of spectators and dozens of reporters and film crews]] On January 11, 1994, [[Ann Schatz]] interviewed Harding at the [[KOIN|KOIN-TV]] station in Portland, Oregon. Schatz asked if she had considered whether someone she knew had planned to attack Nancy. Harding answered "I have definitely thought about it. No one controls my life but me...if there’s something in there that I don’t like, I’m going to change it."{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940113.1.12&srpos=32&e=-------en--20--21-byDA-txt-txIN-%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Husband, bodyguard implicated in attack - Police 'close' to arrest in Kerrigan case|last1=Bruscas|first1=Angelo|last2=Clever|first2=Dick |newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=12|date=Jan 13, 1994|accessdate=2018-08-12}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=4R06DwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=discredit|url-access=subscription|last1=Haight|last2=Vader|first2=J.E. |first1=Abby|title=Fire on Ice|year=1994|page=99|access-date=2018-08-12|quote='I just wish people would see that, you know, I’m out there trying just as much as everybody else is, and it’s just really sad. It’s sad that there’s that kind of people out there.' And she once again expressed her fierce determination. 'No one controls my life but me,' Harding said.}}[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OGdpgWCTSug&t=56s Ann Schatz's 1994 interview with Tonya Harding at KOIN]. ''KOIN 6''. January 11, 1994 Excerpt of Tonya Harding claiming that she doesn't know how Nancy Kerrigan came to be attacked from 0:56 Harding also confirmed she had spoken with [[FBI]] agents while in Detroit and again in Portland.{{cite news|url=https://www.oregonlive.com/tonya-harding/1994/01/fbi_investigating_tonya_hardin.html|title=FBI investigating Tonya Harding's husband as part of alleged plot to sideline figure skater Nancy Kerrigan|last1=Long|first1=James|last2=Hogan|first2=Dave|last3=Haight|first3=Abby|newspaper=The Oregonian|date=Jan 12, 1994|accessdate=2018-08-13}} On January 13, Eckardt and Smith were arrested – Stant surrendered to an FBI office the next day.{{cite news |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/tonya-harding/1994/01/sheriffs_deputies_arrest_tonya.html|title=Sheriff's deputies arrest Tonya Harding's bodyguard & another man in Nancy Kerrigan attack|last1=Long |first1=James |last2=Hogan |first2=Dave |date=Jan 14, 1994 |newspaper=The Oregonian|accessdate=2018-08-13}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/14/us/police-in-oregon-make-arrests-in-assault-on-olympic-skater.html|title=Police in Oregon Make Arrests In Assault on Olympic Skater|first=Timothy|last=Egan |newspaper=New York Times |date=Jan 14, 1994|accessdate=July 13, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_011594.htm|first=William|last=Hamilton|title=Three Held in Assault on Kerrigan|newspaper=Washington Post|date=Jan 15, 1994|accessdate=Aug 13, 2018}} On January 14, the [[United States Figure Skating Association|USFSA]] made a statement regarding whether Eckardt's arrest affected Harding's place on the U.S. Olympic team: "we will deal only with the facts."{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940114.1.13&srpos=1&e=-------en--20--1-byDA-txt-txIN-%22Speculation+where+it+involves+the+careers+of+young+athletes+is+pointless%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Harding keeps Olympic spot - for now|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=13|date=Jan 14, 1994|accessdate=Aug 12, 2018}} Harding and Gillooly's lawyers publicly confirmed the couple were in daily contact and cooperation with law enforcement.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=4R06DwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage|url-access=subscription|last1=Haight|last2=Vader|first2=J.E.|first1=Abby|title=Fire on Ice|year=1994|page=100|access-date=Aug 13, 2018|quote=On Thursday, January 13, Dennis Rawlinson, Harding’s lawyer (and husband of Tonya’s coach), said that she would have plenty to say. The next day, a statement was issued: “Tonya Harding and Jeff Gillooly are meeting today with their lawyers...[They] have cooperated with law enforcement}} On January 15, Harding and Gillooly spoke with reporters, but declined to comment about the investigation.{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940116.1.14&srpos=39&e=-------en--20--21-byDA-txt-txIN-%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Harding chances called 'grim' - New witness says skater knew of plot|last=Wilstein|first=Steve|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=15|date=Jan 16, 1994|accessdate=2018-08-13}} On January 16, Harding's attorney read a [[press-conference|news conference]] statement on her behalf, denying involvement in Kerrigan's attack.{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940117.1.1&srpos=42&e=-------en--20--41-byDA-txt-txIN-%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Harding says she's innocent - 'Tonya is shocked & angry'|last=Wilstein|first=Steve|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=16|date=Jan 17, 1994|accessdate=2018-08-13}} Harding left her home that evening to practice figure skating with her coaches, where she spoke with reporters and performed a triple Axel.{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940118.1.28&srpos=49&e=-------en--20--41-byDA-txt-txIN-%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Harding's ex-husband faces arrest|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=17|date=Jan 18, 1994 |accessdate=2018-08-13}} On January 18, 1994, Harding submitted to questioning by the district attorney and FBI, with her lawyers.{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940119.1.23&srpos=52&e=-------en--20--41-byDA-txt-txIN-%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Officials question Harding|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=18|date=Jan 19, 1994 |accessdate=2018-08-13}}{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-01-19/sports/sp-13203_1_tonya-harding|title=Harding Talks to FBI: Interrogation lasts into night. Skater announces split with ex-husband|first=John|last=Balzar|newspaper=LA Times|date=1994-01-19|accessdate=2018-08-13}} She was interviewed for over 10 hours – 8 hours into the interview, her lawyer issued a statement announcing her separation from Jeff Gillooly: "I continue to believe that Jeff is innocent of any wrongdoing. I wish him nothing but the best."{{cite news|last=Adams|first=Jane Meredith|title=Harding's Controlling Force|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-01-21/news/9401210113_1_harding-and-gillooly-jeff-gillooly-rival-skater-nancy-kerrigan|accessdate=2018-07-08|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=Jan 21, 1994}} Her full FBI transcript was press released on February 1. ''[[The Seattle Times]]'' reported the transcript stating that Harding had "changed her story well into a long interview...After hours of denying any involvement in trying to [[Cover-up|cover up]] the plot, an FBI agent finally 'told [her] that he knew she had lied to him, that he would tell her exactly how she had lied to him'."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/19/sports/figure-skating-harding-stands-firm-in-9-hour-meeting.html|title=Harding Stands Firm In 9-Hour Meeting|first=Micheal|last=Janofsky|newspaper=New York Times|date=Jan 19, 1994|accessdate=2018-09-13}}{{cite news|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19940202&slug=1893162|agency=S.T. The interview ended with this comment from Harding: 'I’m telling on someone I really care about.'}} On January 19, Jeff Gillooly surrendered to the FBI.{{cite news |last=Brennan|first=Christine|title=Rival Skater's Ex-Husband Charged in Attack|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_012094.htm|accessdate=Aug 14, 2018|newspaper=Washington Post|date=Jan 20, 1994}} On January 20, [[Diane Sawyer]] asked Harding on ''[[Primetime (U.S. TV program)|Primetime Live]]'' about the ongoing criminal investigation. Harding's close friend, with whom she was living, spoke to reporters on her behalf: "[Tonya] was shocked, very hurt…She was believing in [Jeff], what he was saying."{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940127.1.1&srpos=70&e=-------en--20--61-byDA-txt-txIN-%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title='Walls are closing in' on skater (1)|first=Bob|last=Baum|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=26|date=Jan 27, 1994|accessdate=Aug 15, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940127.1.10&srpos=1&e=-------en--20--1-byDA-txt-txIN-%22she+was+believing+in+him%22+%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title='Walls are closing in' on skater (2)|first=Bob|last=Baum|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=26|date=Jan 27, 1994|accessdate=July 13, 2018}}{{cite magazine|url=https://www.newsweek.com/tonya-harding-i-know-people-who-love-me-190276|first=Patricia|last=King|title=Tonya Harding: 'I Know The People Who Love Me'|magazine=Newsweek|date=Feb 20, 1994 |accessdate=Aug 15, 2018}} Harding later held an 11am press-conference to read a prepared statement. She said she was sorry Nancy Kerrigan was attacked, that she respected Nancy, and claimed not to know in advance of the plot to disable her. Harding then publicly [[Acceptance of responsibility|took responsibility]] "for failing to report things [about the planned assault] when I returned home from Nationals [on January 10]...my [[Omission (law)|failure to immediately report]] this information is not a crime."{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_012894.htm|title=Harding Admits Knowing of Plot After the Attack|first=Johnette|last=Howard|newspaper=Washington Post |date=Jan 28, 1994 |accessdate=July 6, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1994/01/28/text-of-tonya-hardings-statement/ccff4333-d36d-478d-939e-5a23b175727c/|title=Text of Tonya Harding's Statement|newspaper=Washington Post |date=Jan 28, 1994 |accessdate=July 24, 2018}} Many state laws including [[Oregon]] certify that the act of concealing criminal knowledge alone is not a crime.{{cite web|url=http://www.yossithecriminallawyer.com/concealing-an-offence/|title=Concealing an Offence|website=YossiTheCriminalLawyer.com|department=Blog|date=July 3, 2013|first= Yossi|last=Schochet|accessdate=July 31, 2018|quote=In the U.S. almost every State has rejected criminal prosecution for [[misprision of felony]], primarily for policy reasons, as it encroaches on civil liberties. An exception is the state of South Carolina.}} Nancy Kerrigan's attack had received a lot of publicity; [[news media]] crews had camped outside her home.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_011594.htm|first=William|last=Hamilton|title=Three Held in Assault on Kerrigan|newspaper=Washington Post|date=Jan 15, 1994|accessdate=Aug 16, 2018}} The story was on the covers of ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', ''[[Newsweek]]'', and ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]'' in January 1994.{{cite journal|last1=Martin|first1=Adam|last2=McDonald |first2=Mary G.|url=https://www.worc.ac.uk/gjseper/documents/Covering_womens_sport_An_analysis_of_Sports_Illustrated_covers_2012_1_81-97.pdf|format=PDF|title=Covering women's sport? An analysis of ''Sports Illustrated'' covers from 1987-2009|date=2012 |department=RESULTS - Are there any significant trends in coverage?|journal=Graduate Journal of Sport, Exercise & Physical Education Research|volume=1|page=91|issn=2046-9357|accessdate=Aug 14, 2018|quote=The theme of 'women’s sport as tragic' appeared as a phenomenon among ''Sports Illustrated'' magazine covers in 1993 & 1994. Kerrigan]] cover referencing the physical attack}} There was now much speculation about Harding's own alleged involvement in the assault plot.{{cite magazine |url=http://content.time.com/time/subscriber/article/0,33009,980059-1,00.html|title=What Did Tonya Know?|last=Smolowe |first=J|magazine=Time|date=1994-01-31|accessdate=2017-07-07}}{{cite news| 4, 1994|accessdate=July 12, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/17/sports/sports-of-the-times-harding-s-guilty-plea-anticlimactic.html|first=George|last=Vecsey|title=Harding's Guilty Showdown|newspaper=Washington Post|date=Feb 23, 1994|accessdate=Aug 14, 2018}} Abby Haight and J.E. Vader, journalists for ''[[The Oregonian]]'', wrote a [[biography]] of Harding called ''Fire on Ice'', which included excerpts of her January 18 FBI interview.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/retropolis/wp/2018/01/06/as-crazy-as-it-was-reporters-recall-the-nancy-kerrigan-tonya-harding-feeding-frenzy/|first=Jacob |last=Bogage|title='As crazy as it was': Reporters recall the Tonya Harding-Nancy Kerrigan feeding frenzy |newspaper=Washington Post |date=Jan 8, 2018|accessdate=July 6, 2018}} News media began regularly attending Harding's Portland practices, and unwelcomely recorded footage of her on February 7, running barefoot to stop a tow truck from hauling her illegally parked [[Pickup truck|pickup]].{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1994/02/09/portland-city-under-seige/90e1cfc6-3b86-40a6-9934-6b50c9c0e9ae/|first=Serge F.|last=Kovaleski|title=Portland: City Under Seige|newspaper=Washington Post|date=Feb 9, 1994|accessdate=2018-08-16}} On February 10, [[Connie Chung]] interviewed Harding. When asked about Gillooly, Harding said "I never did anything to hurt [Jeff]. If I ever did anything, it was to stick up for him and protect him."{{cite journal|last1=Benoit|first1=William L.|last2=Hanczor|first2=Robert S.|url=https://vdocuments.site/the-tonya-harding-controversy-an-analysis-of-image-restoration-strategies.html|format=TIFF|title=The Tonya Harding controversy: An analysis of image restoration strategies|date=Fall 1994|journal=[[Communication Quarterly]]|volume=42|issue=4|page=424|doi=10.1080/01463379409369947 |accessdate=2018-09-07}} Chung also negotiated to fly on the same airplane with Harding to [[Oslo]], leaving on February 15, and interviewed her again in Norway. Chung admitted she would not have travelled to Norway were it not for the scandal.{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940216.1.14&srpos=138&e=-------en--20--121-byDA-txt-txIN-%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Tonya hitting town - Kerrigan won't be in hugging mood|last=Rosen|first=Karen|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=46|date=Feb 16, 1994|accessdate=Aug 14, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/22/sports/tv-sports-thirty-seconds-over-lillehammer-on-air-tonya.html|first=Richard|last=Sandomir|title=Thirty Seconds Over Lillehammer on Air Tonya|newspaper=New York Times |date=Feb 22, 1994|accessdate=Aug 14, 2018}} The media frenzy continued on February 17, when Nancy Kerrigan and Harding shared the ice at a practice session in the [[Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre]]. Approximately 400 members of the press were there to document this practice.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_021894.htm|first=Christine |last=Brennan|title=Harding, Kerrigan Practice Together Under Scrutiny|newspaper=Washington Post|date=Feb 18, 1994|accessdate=July 16, 2018}} [[Scott Hamilton (figure skater)|Scott Hamilton]] believed the sport was depicted as a "tabloid event."{{sfn|Hamilton|1999|p=561}} It was noted that Nancy Kerrigan chose to wear the same skating costume at the practice session that she was wearing on January 6.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/18/sports/winter-olympics-for-practice-a-two-ring-circus-in-one-rink.html|first=Jere|last=Longman|title=For Practice, a Two-Ring Circus in One Rink|newspaper=New York Times |date=Feb 18, 1994|accessdate=Aug 14, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940218.1.15&srpos=1&e=-------en--20--1-byDA-txt-txIN-%22a+subtle+reminder+to+tonya%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Tension on ice - Kerrigan, Harding quietly share Olympic practice space|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=48|date=1994-02-18|accessdate=2018-08-14}} Kerrigan later confirmed that her choice of dress that day was deliberate: "[[Humour]] is good, it's empowering."[https://sportsworld.nbcsports.com/nancy-tonya/]. Nancy Kerrigan explaining her decision to wear the same white skating costume on February 17, 1994 - time code ca 0:43:16 The tape-delayed broadcast of the February 23 Ladies' Olympic technical program remains one of the most watched telecasts in American history.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.variety.com/index.asp?layout=chart_pass&charttype=chart_topshowsalltime|magazine=Variety|author=Nielsen Media Research|title=Top 100 TV Shows of All Time|date=Aug 6, 2000|accessdate=2018-07-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090315021343/http://www.variety.com/index.asp?layout=chart_pass&charttype=chart_topshowsalltime|archivedate=March 15, 2009}}{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/24/business/the-media-business-winter-olympics-ratings-on-record-pace-for-cbs.html|first=Richard|last=Sandomir|title=Winter Olympics Ratings On Record Pace for CBS |newspaper=New York Times|date=Feb 24, 1994|accessdate=July 17, 2018}} [[File:Hamar crop.jpg|thumb|Hamar crop|Figure skating competitions for the 1994 Winter Olympics were held in the [[CC Amfi]], formerly known as the Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre.]] On February 5, 1994, the disciplinary panel of the U.S. Figure Skating Association stated that [[Reasonable suspicion|reasonable grounds]] existed to believe Harding had violated the sport's [[Ethical code|code of ethics]].{{cite web |url=https://www.scribd.com/document/222926632/Harding-v-USOC-Exhibit-USFSA-Disciplinary-Charges|title=Harding's Disciplinary Charges|website=Scribd |date=1994-02-05|accessdate=2018-08-27}} Her admitted failure to report information about an assault on a fellow competitor, supported by her FBI interview transcripts, resulted in Harding being [[Professional ethics|formally charged]] with "[making] false statements about her knowledge." The panel also recommended that she face a disciplinary hearing. [[Claire Waters Ferguson|Claire Ferguson]], president of the USFSA, decided not to suspend Harding's membership before any hearing took place. If Harding had been suspended, she likely still would have competed at the Winter Olympics after filing an [[injunction]] on the USFSA and asserting her rights under the [[Amateur Sports Act of 1978]].{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/28/sports/figure-skating-harding-to-get-olympic-spot-but-inquiry-continues.html|title=Harding to Get Olympic Spot but Inquiry Continues|newspaper=New York Times|first=Jere|last=Longman|date=Jan 28, 1994|access-date=2018-07-31}} Evidence examined by the panel included the testimonies of Stant and Smith, Harding and Gillooly's telephone records, and notes found in a Portland saloon trash receptacle on January 30.{{cite web|url=https://bleacherreport.com/articles/1887592-harding-kerrigan-20-years-later-remembering-the-stunning-life-changing-attack|first=Matt|last=Crossman|title=Harding-Kerrigan 20 Years Later: Remembering the Stunning Attack|department=The Evidence in the Dumpster|website=Bleacher Report, Inc|date=Dec 19, 2013|accessdate=July 20, 2018}} Harding was given 30 days to respond.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/06/sports/winter-olympics-harding-ordered-to-appear-at-hearing.html|title=Harding Ordered To Appear At Hearing|newspaper=New York Times|first=Jere|last=Longman|date=Feb 6, 1994|access-date=July 20, 2018}} On March 9, Judge [[Owen M. Panner|Owen Panner]] granted her a requested [[Stay of proceedings|halt]] on the 30-day deadline to delay her disciplinary hearing until June 27.{{cite web |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/210813255/USFSA-s-decision-regarding-Tonya-Harding |title=USFSA's decision regarding Tonya Harding |website=Scribd |date=June 30, 1994 |accessdate=July 4, 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1994/03/22/jury-harding-in-on-plot/966b6613-14e9-4fcd-a2fc-c585deb3f4fc/|title=Jury: Harding in on Plot|newspaper=Washington Post|first=Johnette|last=Howard|date=March 22, 1994|access-date=July 24, 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/11/sports/a-clear-path-for-harding.html|title=Clear Path for Harding|newspaper=New York Times|date=1994-03-11|access-date=2018-07-21}} Meanwhile, Portland authorities stated the criminal investigation would conclude by March 21 with any [[indictment]]s and a [[Grand juries in the United States|grand jury]] report to be made at that time.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_021594.htm|title=Thousands Watch Harding's Final Portland Workout|newspaper=Washington Post|first=Christine|last=Spolar|date=Feb 15, 1994|access-date=July 21, 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/20/sports/figure-skating-harding-deal-handed-something-to-both-sides.html|title=Harding Deal Handed Something to Both Sides|newspaper=New York Times|first=Jere|last=Longman|date=March 20, 1994|access-date=July 24, 2018}} On March 16, 1994, Harding pleaded guilty to [[Obstruction of justice|conspiracy to hinder prosecution]] as a [[Classes of offenses under United States federal law|Class C felony offense]] at a [[Multnomah County]] court hearing. She and her lawyer, Robert Weaver, negotiated a plea bargain ensuring no further prosecution.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_031794.htm|title=Harding Admits Guilt in Plea Bargain, Avoids Prison|newspaper=Washington Post|first=Johnette|last=Howard|date=March 17, 1994|access-date=July 23, 2018}} Judge Donald Londer conducted routine questioning to make certain Harding understood her agreement, that she was entering her plea "knowingly and voluntarily." Harding told Londer she was. Her plea admissions were [[Knowledge (legal construct)|knowing]] of the assault plot after the fact, settling on a cover story with Gillooly and Eckardt on January 10, witnessing payphone calls to Smith affirming the story on January 10 and 11, and lying to FBI with the story on January 18.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_020294.htm|title=Gillooly Pleads Guilty, Says Harding Approved Plot|last=Buckley|first=Stephen|date=Feb 2, 1994|newspaper=Washington Post|accessdate=June 23, 2018}}{{cite news |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1994-02-02/news/9402020823_1_nancy-kerrigan-tonya-harding-eckardt|title=Harding's ex-husband says she helped to plan attack - Attorney: 'What Did Tonya Know And When?'|date=Feb 2, 1994|newspaper=Orlando Sentinel|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} Law enforcement investigators had been following and videotaping the co-conspirators since January 10; they knew about the payphone calls.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_012394.htm|department=Chronology of Kerrigan Attack|title=Tonya Harding Remains the Public Enigma|last=Brennan|first=Christine|date=Jan 23, 1994|newspaper=Washington Post|accessdate=Aug 2, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/01/sports/figure-skating-lawyer-for-skater-s-ex-husband-says-he-has-tied-her-to-attack.html|title=Lawyer for Skater's Ex-Husband Says He Has Tied Her to Attack|newspaper=New York Times|first=Michael|last=Janofsky|date=Feb 1, 1994|accessdate=Aug 2, 2018}} Her penalties included 3 years of [[probation]], $100,000 [[Fine (penalty)|fine]], and 500 hours [[community service]]. She agreed to reimburse Multnomah County $10,000 in legal expenses, undergo a [[Psychiatric assessment|psychiatric examination]], and volunteered to give $50,000 to the [[Special Olympics]] Oregon (SOOR) charity.{{cite web |url=http://www.soor.org/Sub-Page.aspx?name=About-Special-Olympics-Oregon&PID=2|title=Special Olympics Oregon|website=Soor.org |accessdate=July 24, 2018}} Oregon [[sentencing guidelines]] carried a max penalty of 5-years-prison for the offense.{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-03-17/news/mn-35216_1_figure-skating-team|title=Harding Pleads Guilty to Obstructing Justice. fees.{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_020294a.htm|first=Mark|last=Asher|title=Nike Steps Up With $25,000 for Harding's Skating Championships|World Championships]] (for which she was scheduled to leave tomorrow).{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/17/sports/figure-skating-judge-accepts-harding-plea-in-conspiracy.html|title=Judge Accepts Harding Plea In Conspiracy|newspaper=New York Times|first=Michael|last=Janofsky|date=March 17, 1994|access-date=July 23, 2018}} District attorney Norman Frink stated that if Harding had not agreed to the plea, "we would have proceeded with an indictment on all possible charges...punishment was taking away [skating] privilege."{{cite news |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/tonya-harding/2014/01/tonya_harding-nancy_kerrigan_h.html|title=Harding found guilty of hindering investigation |last1=Long |first1=James |last2=Hogan |first2=Dave |date=March 17, 1994 |newspaper=The Oregonian|accessdate=June 23, 2018}} Weaver said the plea agreement was satisfactory to Harding, partly because she avoided prison. Regarding [[Right to a fair trial|trial]] concerns, he stated "we would have prevailed at trial."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/18/sports/figure-skating-harding-plea-bargain-is-called-a-time-saver.html|title=Harding Plea Bargain Is Called a Time-Saver|last=Janofsky|first=Michael|date=March 18, 1994|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} An executive of the USFSA commented "[We] don't know if Tonya is innocent or guilty...if [she was involved before] the national championship."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/17/sports/figure-skating-skating-group-is-angry-kerrigan-is-silent.html|title=Skating Group Is Angry; Kerrigan Is Silent|last=Longman|first=Jere|date=March 17, 1994|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} On March 18, Claire Ferguson decided Harding's disciplinary hearing would still proceed in June. The USFSA's executive committee convened to discuss their position should Harding seek reinstatement and whether they might strip her of the 1994 National Championship title. Neither issue was decided at that time.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/18/sports/figure-skating-skating-association-schedules-hearing-in-june-on-harding.html|title=Skating Association Schedules Hearing in June on Harding|last=Longman|first=Jere|date=March 18, 1994|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} [[File:Tonya harding returning from norway 1994.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1|Harding arriving at [[Portland International Airport]] amid a crush of reporters after the 1994 Olympics]] On March 21, 1994, a Portland grand jury issued an indictment stating there was evidence Harding participated in the attack plot. The indictment concluded more than two months of investigation and witness testimonies from Diane Rawlinson, Erika Bakacs (Harding's choreographer), Eckardt's college instructor and classmates, and Vera Marano (a freelance figure skating writer in Philadelphia).{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_012194.htm|title=Bodyguard Says Harding Knew of Plot|newspaper=Washington Post|first=Christine|last=Brennan|date=Jan 21, 1994|access-date=July 31, 2018}}{{cite news|newspaper=Seattle Post-Intelligencer|url=https://www.deseretnews.com/article/334609/RECORDS-INDICATE-HARDING-LIED-ABOUT-PHONE-CALLS.html|title=Records Indicate Harding Lied About Phone Calls|date=Feb 4, 1994|first=Angelo|last=Bruscas|accessdate=Aug 2, 2018}} It stated there was evidence Harding fraudulently used USFSA provided skating monies to finance the assault. It also read that Harding, Gillooly, Eckardt, Smith, and Stant agreed to "knowingly cause physical injury...by means of a dangerous weapon." The grand jury foreman said the evidence inferred Harding as "involved from the beginning or very close." She was not charged in the indictment due to the terms of her March 16 plea agreement.{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-03-22/sports/sp-36995_1_nancy-kerrigan|title=Indictment Says Harding Involved in Kerrigan Plot|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|agency=Associated Press|date=March 22, 1994|access-date=July 25, 2018}} On June 29, the USFSA disciplinary panel met for nine hours over two days to consider Harding's alleged role in the attack.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/06/30/sports/sports-people-figure-skating-harding-punishment-under-consideration.html|title=Harding Punishment Under Consideration|date=June 30, 1994|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=Aug 11, 2018}} On June 30, chairman William Hybl stated "By a [[Burden of proof (law)|preponderance of the evidence]], the panel did conclude that she had prior knowledge and was involved prior to the incident. This is based on [[Civil procedure in the United States|civil standards]], not [[United States criminal procedure|criminal standards]]...bank records, phone records – the way they came together to establish a case." The panel decided that pertinent FBI reports, court documents, and Harding's March 16 plea agreement presented "a clear disregard for fairness, good sportsmanship, and ethical behaviour." Harding chose neither to attend nor participate in the two-day hearing. Robert Weaver said the decision disappointed her but was not a surprise, and that she had not decided on an appeal.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_070194.htm|title=Harding Stripped of Title; Banned for Life|first=Christine |last=Brennan |newspaper=Washington Post |date=July 1, 1994 |accessdate=June 24, 2018}} Harding was stripped of the 1994 U.S. Championship title and banned for life from participating in USFSA events as either skater or coach. The USFSA has no dominion over professional skating events, yet Harding was also ''[[persona non grata]]'' on the pro circuit, few skaters and promoters would work with her. She did not benefit from the ensuing boom in professional skating after the scandal.{{sfn|Hamilton|Benet|1999|pages=558, 585}} Shortly before the [[1998 Winter Olympics]], the [[CBS News|CBS]] and [[Fox Sports|Fox]] news divisions re-examined the scandal for two televised [[special report]]s.{{cite news|url=https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/specials/olympics/nagano/021798oly-tv-sports.html|title=TV Sports: CBS Provides Entertaining Moments|first=Richard|last=Sandomir|newspaper=New York Times|date=Feb 17, 1998 |accessdate=July 6, 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://apnews.com/2778394bd828127ee9f32fb76299fa55 |title=Nancy & Tonya, Together|first=J|last=Dubow |newspaper=AP|date=1998-02-05|accessdate=2018-07-04}} [[Harry Smith (American journalist)|Harry Smith]] hosted the CBS special. He reported that Harding still held to her statement from her press-conference given on January 27, 1994: "I had no prior knowledge of the planned assault on Nancy Kerrigan." Smith then interviewed Kerrigan, asking how she responded to that statement. Nancy Kerrigan referred to transcripts she had read from Harding's FBI interview on January 18, 1994. After reading through the interrogation of that day, she concluded that "[Tonya] knew more than she admits."{{cite magazine|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1994/03/07/130609/silver-belle-nancy-kerrigan-conquered-her-demons-but-couldnt-overcome-a-pixie-from-ukraine|first=E. M.|last=Swift|title=Silver Belle|magazine=Sports Illustrated |date=1994-03-07|accessdate=2018-07-07}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1994/02/05/a-case-of-he-said-she-said/e85b11fd-e964-40f8-a3f6-1196083d2dd5/|title=A Case of He Said, She Said|first=Stephen|last=Buckley|newspaper=Washington Post |date=Feb 5, 1994|accessdate=2018-07-06}} The Fox special report was called ''Breaking the Ice: The Women of '94 Revisited'', hosted by [[James Brown (sportscaster)|James Brown]] with interviews from Harding, Gillooly, and Kerrigan.{{cite news|url=https://newsok.com/article/2601780/fox-relives-figure-skating-feud-tonight|title=Fox Relives Figure Skating Feud Tonight|first=Mel|last=Bracht|newspaper=The Oklahoman|date=Feb 5, 1998|accessdate=July 6, 2018}} Jeff Gillooly (granted a [[name change]] to Jeff Stone in 1995){{cite news |url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/1995/jul/22/man-who-clubbed-kerrigan-skates-from-jail-former/ |title=Man Who Clubbed Kerrigan Skates From Jail Former Cda Strongman Stant Says He's Sorry For Attack|newspaper=Spokesman-Review|date=July 22, 1995|accessdate=2018-07-04}} said Harding's prison evasion did not anger him, and that he felt his own punishment was just. Stone reflected on Harding's position of "limited involvement" in Kerrigan's attack and speculated that a "guilty conscience" still troubled her. Brown then mediated a joint interview with both Kerrigan and Harding present. The two former competitors shared sincere desires for happy families and general well-wishes toward one other. Nancy Kerrigan said she hoped Harding could learn from past mistakes and "find happiness."{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1998/02/08/for-openers-many-eyes-were-closed/2f226bf6-6cb3-422c-9ffe-d1c55790b5b6/|title=For Openers, Many Eyes were Closed|first=Leonard|last=Shapiro |newspaper=Washington Post |date=Feb 8, 1998 |accessdate=July 5, 2018}} Harding said she was grateful to personally express remorse to Kerrigan again.{{cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1998-02-06/sports/9802060057_1_harding-and-kerrigan-harding-s-ex-husband-nancy-kerrigan |title=Harding's Apology Rejected|first=Sharon|last=Robb |newspaper=Sun-Sentinel |date=Feb 6, 1998 |accessdate=July 5, 2018}} In Harding's 2008 biography, ''The Tonya Tapes'' (transcribed by Lynda D. Prouse from recorded interviews), she stated that she wanted to call the FBI in 1994 to reveal what she knew, but decided not to when Gillooly allegedly threatened her with death following a gunpoint gang rape by him and two other men she did not know. Jeff (Gillooly) Stone responded with surprise that groundless claims against him could be published and specifically contended her gang rape accusation to be "utterly ridiculous."{{cite web|url=https://www.today.com/news/tonya-harding-reveals-her-side-roller-coaster-life-1C9015579 |title=Tonya Harding reveals her side of 'roller-coaster life'|date=May 15, 2008|first=Mike|last=Celizic |accessdate=July 4, 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170901024350/https://www.today.com/news/tonya-harding-reveals-her-side-roller-coaster-life-1C9015579|archivedate=2017-09-01}} In 2013, ''[[Deadspin]]'' sought Jeff Stone for an interview and he again defended himself from the gunpoint gang rape allegation. Yet he expressed regret that Harding is often "remembered for what I talked her into doing," meaning allegedly plotting to injure Nancy Kerrigan.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/02/sports/figure-skating-what-gillooly-says-and-what-harding-says.html|title=What Gillooly Says, and What Harding Says |first=Joseph B. |last=Treaster |newspaper=New York Times |date=Feb 2, 1994|accessdate=2018-06-22}}{{cite magazine |url=https://www.si.com/vault/1994/02/14/130460/anatomy-of-a-plot-even-in-their-version-of-events----which-differs-from-tonya-hardings----the-confessed-conspirators-in-the-nancy-kerrigan-assault-were-at-once-goons-and-buffoons |first=E. M. |last=Swift |title=Anatomy of a Plot |magazine=Sports Illustrated|date=Feb 14, 1994|accessdate=2016-11-28}}{{cite magazine |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140226105257/https://lostangelesca.tumblr.com/post/10912671075/whats-more-fun-than-a-good-old-fashioned-tonya-harding|archivedate=2014-02-26|url=https://lostangelesca.tumblr.com/post/10912671075/whats-more-fun-than-a-good-old-fashioned-tonya-harding|deadurl=yes|first=Randall|last=Sullivan|title=The Tonya Harding Fall|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=July 14, 1994|issue=686/687|page=80|url-access=registration|via=EBSCOhost|quote=Jeff saw [Tonya] for the first time in six days on...Jan. 25...loading their furniture into the bed of the blue Ford pickup. Tonya told him, "I just want you to know that I really do appreciate you taking the blame for all this," Jeff recalled, then asked for a hug. The FBI already had enough to arrest her, Jeff warned. They couldn't prove anything, Tonya replied. She said, "Good luck," Jeff recalled, squeezed his hand, gave him a wink and left. It was the last time he saw her.|accessdate=2018-08-29}} Stone admitted that his past stupidity was part of Harding's 1994 ruin and maintained that he still considered her a great figure skater. He also said "I've had it easy, compared to poor Tonya...she tends to be the butt of the joke. It's kind of sad to me."{{cite news |url=https://deadspin.com/finding-gillooly-what-happened-to-figure-skatings-inf-1482669790 |title=Finding Gillooly|last=Nelson |first=Amy K. |date=Dec 13, 2013|access-date=2018-06-21}} In 2014, Nancy Kerrigan addressed the scandal during a brief interview with sportscaster [[Bob Costas]]: "Whatever apology Tonya has given, I accept it. It's time for all us – I've always wished [Tonya] well – she has her own family, I have my family. It's time to make that our focus and move on with our lives."[https://sportsworld.nbcsports.com/nancy-tonya/]. ''NBC SportsWorld''. ''Nancy & Tonya'' (2014) documentary. The night's performance included [[Art Barr]] and [[Eddie Guerrero]].{{sfn|Guerrero|2005|pages=100–1}} A promotional musical event was unsuccessful when Harding and her band, the Golden Blades, were booed off the stage at their only performance, in 1995 in Portland, Oregon.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20101626,00.html |title=Stage Fright|magazine=People|date=1995-09-18 |accessdate=2013-04-19|number=12 |volume=44}}{{cite news |url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19950830&slug=2139013 |title=Tonya Harding Debuts As Singer In Portland Concert For MDA |newspaper=Seattle Times |date=Aug 30, 1995 |accessdate=2013-04-19}} In 1994, Harding was cast in a low-budget action film, ''Breakaway''. Harding's boxing career came about amid rumors that she was having financial difficulties and needed to fight in the ring to earn money.{{cite news |title=Tonya Harding Loses in Pro Boxing Debut |url=http://www.ourmidland.com/news/article/Tonya-Harding-Loses-in-Pro-Boxing-Debut-7070027.php |first=Barry |last=Wilner |date=Feb 21, 2003 |newspaper=Midland Daily News}} She did another celebrity boxing match, on ''[[The Man Show]]'', and won against co-host [[Doug Stanhope]]. Stanhope later claimed on his podcast that the fight was fixed because Tonya Harding refused to "fight a man."{{cite web |url=http://stanhope.libsyn.com/ep-22-comedian-andy-andrist-pt2 |title=Ep. #22: Comedian Andy Andrist - Pt.2 |website=The Doug Stanhope Podcast |accessdate=June 5, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808143606/http://stanhope.libsyn.com/ep-22-comedian-andy-andrist-pt2 |archivedate=August 8, 2016 }} On March 23, 2004, it was reported that she canceled a planned boxing match against Tracy Carlton in [[Oakland, California]], because of an alleged death threat against her.{{cite news |title=Why Harding wasn't in bout / Manager cites death threats, skills of foe |url=http://www.sfgate.com/sports/article/Why-Harding-wasn-t-in-bout-Manager-cites-death-2777303.php |first=Dwight |last=Chapin |date=March 23, 2004 |accessdate=2017-12-28|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle}} On June 24, 2004, after reportedly not having boxed for over a year, she was beaten in a match in [[Edmonton]], Alberta, by Amy Johnson. She gave birth to her only child, a son named Gordon, on February 19, 2011.{{cite magazine |url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2011/02/23/tonya-harding-welcomes-a-son/#more-126909 |title=Tonya Harding welcomes a son |date=Feb 23, 2011 |first=Mike |last=Fleeman |magazine=People |accessdate=2011-02-27}} Since leaving skating and boxing, Harding has worked as a welder, a painter at a metal fabrication company, and a hardware sales clerk at Sears.{{cite news |last1=Brodesser-Akner |first1=Taffy |authorlink=Taffy Brodesser-Akner |title=Tonya Harding Would Like Her Apology Now |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/10/movies/tonya-harding-i-tonya-nancy-kerrigan-scandal.html |accessdate=2018-01-10|newspaper=New York Times |date=2018-01-10}} As of 2017, she stated that she worked as a painter and deck builder.{{cite av media|title=I, Tonya|people=Gillespie, Craig (dir.)|year=2017|publisher=Neon Films}} She resides in [[Washington (state)|Washington]] state, north of her hometown of Portland, Oregon. On an appearance on ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'' on February 26, 2018, Harding stated that she is still active in skating and practices three times a week. In a segment during the show, she performed several jumps and spins. She trains with her former coach, Dody Teachman.{{cite web|title=Tonya Harding on her continued love for figure skating & what her life is like today|author1=Rakowski, Cat |author2= Valiente, Alexa|date=Jan 11, 2018|accessdate=2018-02-05|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/tonya-harding-continued-love-figure-skating-life-today/story?id=52260238|work=ABC News}} == Cultural significance == Harding still receives criticism.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/columnist/brennan/2017/12/20/tonya-harding-movie-wants-your-sympathy-but-lets-not-forget-facts/971183001/|title=Tonya Harding movie wants your sympathy, but let's not forget the facts|first=Christine|last=Brennan |newspaper=USA Today|date=December 20, 2017|accessdate=July 26, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://deadspin.com/how-much-sympathy-does-tonya-harding-deserve-1822095036|title=How Much Sympathy Does Tonya Harding Deserve?|website=Deadspin|first=Dvora|last=Meyers|date=January 17, 2018|accessdate=July 26, 2018}}{{cite magazine |url=https://people.com/movies/tonya-harding-was-involved-up-to-her-neck-in-the-nancy-kerrigan-attack-says-oregon-da/|first=Mia|last=McNiece|title=Tonya Harding 'Was Involved Up to Her Neck' in the Nancy Kerrigan Attack, Says Oregon DA|publisher=Meredith Corporation|magazine=People|date=January 31, 2018|accessdate=July 26, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.oregonlive.com/trending/2018/01/i_nauseated_the_oregonians_for.html|title='I, Nauseated': The Oregonian's ex-sports columnist nails what the Tonya Harding movie gets wrong|first=J.E.|last=Vader|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]]|date=Jan 29, 2018|accessdate=July 26, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2018/02/i_was_tonya_hardings_prosecuto.html|title='I, Tonya'? Well, I prosecuted. And Tonya Harding was guilty as charged|first=Norm|last=Frink|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]]|date=February 24, 2018 |accessdate=July 26, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2018/07/falling-out-of-love-with-tonya-harding.html#|title=Falling Out of Love With Tonya Harding|website=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|first=Jamie|last=Loftus|date=July 19, 2018 |accessdate=July 26, 2018}} However, her life, career, and role in the Kerrigan attack have been widely referenced in popular culture; appearing in television, film, music, as well as a [[Democratic Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2008|primary campaign]] speech by former President [[Barack Obama]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/deadlineusa/2009/mar/04/tonya-harding-barack-obama-name-kneecap |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |title=Tonya Harding bitter and thankful over Obama's 'kneecap' comment |date=March 4, 2009 |accessdate=May 25, 2010 |first=Paul |last=Lester}} In 2014, Matt Harkins and Viviana Olen created the Nancy Kerrigan and Tonya Harding Museum in their [[Brooklyn, New York]], apartment, dedicated to collecting and archiving memorabilia related to Harding and the incident.{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2015/04/19/400736119/like-dynasty-on-ice-the-nancy-kerrigan-and-tonya-harding-museum |title=Like 'Dynasty' On Ice: The Nancy Kerrigan And Tonya Harding Museum |website=NPR |date=April 19, 2015 |accessdate=Dec 28, 2016}} Harkins and Olen stated in a 2017 interview that they had been captivated by Harding's life for years, citing it as "the most American story ever told."{{cite web|work=Vulture|title=Cult of Tonya Harding|date=Dec 6, 2017|accessdate=January 18, 2018|url=http://www.vulture.com/2017/12/the-cult-of-tonya-harding.html|author1=Olen, Viviana |author2= Harkins, Matt}} A contemporaneous article published in ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' also noted that Harding had developed a "[[cult following]]" in the years since her notoriety.{{cite web|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/fashion-runway-i-tonya-costumes-90s-fashion|work=Vogue|title=I, Tonya's Costume Designer on Why She Didn't Want to Take a Cheap Shot at '90s Fashion|author=Bobb, Brooke|date=Dec 8, 2017|accessdate=January 30, 2018}} === Representation in other media === * ''Sharp Edges'' (1986), filmmaker Sandra Luckow's senior-thesis project documentary for her [[Film studies]] major at [[Yale University]]. Luckow was Harding's childhood friend, and the documentary followed Harding and her coaches to [[Uniondale, New York]] as she competed in the February [[1986 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]]. The film featured interviews with Harding, her mother and coaches, discussing her career in figure skating.{{cite magazine|last=Gleiberman|first=Owen|title=Film Review: The 1986 Tonya Harding Documentary ‘Sharp Edges’|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/reviews/film-review-sharp-edges-tonya-harding-1986-1202865442/|accessdate=August 12, 2018|magazine=Variety|date=July 4, 2018}} * ''Spunk: The Tonya Harding Story'' (1994), [[Comedy Central]] five-minute [[short film]] [[parody]] summarizing the scandal, estimated to have aired on February 25, 1994.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0195301/releaseinfo?|title=Spunk: Tonya Harding Story - Release Dates|website=IMDb|accessdate=2018-08-28}} [[Tina Yothers]] portrayed Harding as perpetually misunderstood, but universally admired for her "spunk." * [[Tonya and Nancy: The Inside Story|''Tonya & Nancy: The Inside Story'' (1994)]], NBC [[television film]] based on [[public domain]] material, premiered on April 30, 1994; directed by [[Larry Shaw (director)|Larry Shaw]] and written by previous [[Edgar Award]] winner Phil Penningroth.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0672150/awards?|title=Phil Penningroth - Awards|website=IMDb|accessdate=July 18, 2018}} [[Alexandra Powers]] portrayed Harding and [[Heather Langenkamp]] portrayed Nancy Kerrigan. It featured a [[Postmodernism|postmodern]] breaking of the [[fourth wall]] by having [[Dennis Boutsikaris]] play the film's screenwriter, addressing the audience over the course of the story. One of the last lines in the film was "We imprisoned [Tonya and Nancy] in images we use to sell newspapers, soup, and TV movies. They're victims of those that the media serve."{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/1994/tv/reviews/tonya-nancy-the-inside-story-1200436535/|title=Tonya & Nancy: The Inside Story|last=Loynd|first=Ray|date=April 29, 1994|website=Variety|access-date=2018-09-13}} * [[Attack of the 5 Ft. 2 In. Brown's original song for the segment, "Queen of the Ice," was nominated for a [[CableACE Award]].{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/article/1994/08/19/national-lampoons-attack-52-women/|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|title=National Lampoon's Attack of the 5'2" Women|accessdate=Dec 30, 2017|date=Aug 19, 1994 |author=Schwarzbaum, Lisa}}{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109167/awards?|title=Attack of the 5 Ft. 2 In. Brockhampton; lyrics}} * ''Tonya & Nancy: The Rock Opera'' (2006), novelist and playwright [[Elizabeth Searle]] collaborated with composer Abigail Al-Doory in May 2006 to create a chamber opera produced by [[Tufts University]] and directed by Meron Langsner. Described as a dark comedy, it premiered in [[Portland, Oregon]] in 2008.{{cite news |url=http://portlandtribune.com/pt/11-features/63312-tonya--and--nancy-the-rock-opera-%E2%80%A2-soap-on-ice |title=Tonya & Nancy: The Rock Opera • Soap on ice |last=Bartels |first=Eric |date=Feb 18, 2008 |newspaper=Portland Tribune|access-date=Dec 21, 2017 |language=en-gb}} It was also produced in Los Angeles, New York and Chicago. Searle said that she thought elements of the 1994 scandal reflected "life in America," and that she hoped the show would convey public sympathy towards Nancy Kerrigan, Jeff Gillooly, and Tonya Harding.{{cite news|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/sports/other-sports/no-escape-from-past-for-harding/|title=No escape from past for Harding|date=Dec 22, 2007|last=Mellinger|first=Sam|newspaper=Seattle Times|accessdate=Aug 12, 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://archive.boston.com/bostonglobe/ideas/articles/2008/01/13/qa_with_elizabeth_searle/?page=1|title=Q&A with Elizabeth Searle|date=Jan 13, 2008 |last= Kennedy |first=Pagan|newspaper=The Boston Globe|accessdate=Aug 12, 2018}} * ''The Price of Gold'' (2014) documentary directed by [[Nanette Burstein]], part of [[ESPN]]'s ''[[30 for 30]]'' series, aired on January 16, 2014. The documentary explored some specifics of the criminal investigation involving Nancy Kerrigan's attack. Kerrigan herself could not be interviewed for ''The Price of Gold'' because of her contractual obligation to NBC's ''Nancy & Tonya'' (2014) documentary. Burstein stated she intended her documentary to be "predominantly about Tonya."{{cite web |url=https://www.sbs.com.au/guide/article/2018/01/17/director-nanette-burstein-her-tonya-harding-documentary-price-gold|title=Director Nanette Burstein on her Tonya Harding documentary|last=Weber|first=Lindsey|website=SBS (Australian channel)|date=Feb 5, 2018|accessdate=2018-07-11}} After the film was completed, Burstein said that she thought Harding was jealous of Kerrigan{{cite web|url=http://getinmedia.com/articles/film-tv-careers/director-nanette-burstein-revisits-tonya-harding-and-nancy-kerrigan-20-year|title=Director Nanette Burstein Revisits Tonya Harding & Nancy Kerrigan|last=Donnelly|first=Billy|website=Get In Media|date=2014|accessdate=July 11, 2018}} and that "[Tonya] was an unreliable interview subject. A lot of things she said had to be left out because I didn't think they were truthful."{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/lifestyle/nancy-kerrigan-tonya-harding-documentary-3036674|title=20 years on from the ice skating assault that shocked the world|date=Jan 19, 2014|newspaper=Daily Mirror|accessdate=July 11, 2018}} * ''Nancy & Tonya'' (2014), [[NBC]] documentary narrated by Olympics correspondent [[Mary Carillo]] (former [[tennis]] professional - [[1977 French Open]] [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam]] Mixed Doubles winner), aired on February 23, 2014. It included interviews, brief biographies of Nancy Kerrigan & Tonya Harding, and close observations of their lives and careers before 1994.{{cite news|url=https://www.denverpost.com/2014/02/20/tonya-harding-vs-nancy-kerrigan-nbc-documentary-recalls-an-early-tv-tabloid-story/|title=NBC documentary recalls an early TV tabloid story|date=Feb 20, 2014|first=Joanne |last=Ostrow|newspaper=The Denver Post|accessdate=July 11, 2018}}{{cite magazine|last=Deitsch|first=Richard|title=Nancy Kerrigan opens up about 'the whack heard 'round the world'|url=https://www.si.com/olympics/2014/02/21/nancy-kerrigan-tonya-harding-nbc-documentary|accessdate=July 12, 2018|magazine=Sports Illustrated|date=Feb 21, 2014}} * ''Tonya Harding: The Musical'' (2014), comedy-musical written by Jesse Esparza, with songs by Manny Hagopian, performed at the [[Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre]] in Los Angeles.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/12/theater/tonya-harding-nancy-kerrigan-figure-skating.html|last=Piepenburg|first=Erik|title=Tonya Harding, Tragic Muse?|newspaper=New York Times|date=June 12, 2017|accessdate=Feb 10, 2018}} * ''T.'' (2017) a [[Play (theatre)|play]] written by Dan Aibel, premiered in Chicago on May 25, 2017 at the American Theater Company; directed by Margot Bordelon with Harding portrayed by Leah Raidt. Mary Houlihan of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' called it "a mildly interesting take on a somewhat tired topic." She liked how the play explored issues of class and competition, as well as Raidt's performance – yet thought it lacked Harding's "edgy toughness." Houlihan also admired Kelli Simpkins' performance as "Joanne," Harding's coach. She praised Bordelon's direction for "[steering] the actors away from any broad, [[Camp (style)|campy]] interpretation" and Aibel's writing for "deftly [capturing] the despicable side of the story."{{cite news|url=https://chicago.suntimes.com/entertainment/t-stage-drama-revisits-the-still-fascinating-kerrigan-harding-saga/|url-access=limited|last=Houlihan|first=Mary|title='T.' stage drama revisits the still-fascinating Kerrigan-Harding saga|date=May 27, 2017|newspaper=Chicago Sun-Times|accessdate=Aug 22, 2018}} * [[I, Tonya|''I, Tonya'' (2017)]], biographical [[black comedy]] film directed by [[Craig Gillespie]] with [[Margot Robbie]] playing Harding, premiered at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] on September 8, 2017.{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-ca-mn-sneaks-i-tonya-screenwriter-20171105-story.html|first=Geoff|last=Berkshire |title=How 'I, Tonya' screenwriter Steven Rogers reinvented himself|newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=Nov 3, 2017 |accessdate=Aug 2, 2018}} It was theatrically released on December 8 to mostly positive reviews, yet it played in no more than 1,450 theatres in the United States and Canada.{{cite web|url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=itonya.htm|title=I, Tonya: Domestic Summary|department=Widest Release: 1,450 theatres|website=BoxOfficeMojo.com|accessdate=Aug 3, 2018}} Screenwriter [[Steven Rogers (screenwriter)|Steven Rogers]] was nominated for a [[BAFTA Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay BAFTA]]; he said he neither knew nor cared about Harding's alleged part in Nancy Kerrigan's attack, that the film was really about "things we tell ourselves in order to...live with ourselves...how we change the [[narrative]], and then want that to be the narrative."{{cite magazine|url=https://www.newsweek.com/tonya-harding-movie-steven-rogers-740186|first=Janice|last=Williams|title=Who is Tonya Harding? Ice Skater's Life Serves as 'Cautionary Tale' says 'I, Tonya' Screenwriter|magazine=Newsweek|date=Dec 7, 2017| accessdate=Aug 3, 2018}}{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2017/12/i-tonya-harding-movie|title=The Surreal Story of How Tonya Harding Inspired Awards Season's Scrappiest Contender|last=Miller|first=Julie|date=Dec 6, 2017|magazine=Vanity Fair|accessdate=Aug 3, 2018}} Gillespie was nominated for a [[AACTA International Award for Best Direction|Best Director AACTA]]; he said he believed Harding was guilty, but debated to what degree. Gillespie also said he wanted the film to convey "why [Tonya] is the way she is."{{Cite web|url=http://iris.theaureview.com/interview-director-craig-gillespie-on-taking-no-prisoners-when-filming-i-tonya/|date=Jan 25, 2018|title=Craig Gillespie on Filming I, Tonya|last=Gray|first=Peter |website=Iris.theAUreview.com |department=The Iris|language=en-AU|access-date=Aug 3, 2018}} Robbie, who also [[Film producer|produced]] the film, was nominated for a [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Comedy or Musical|Best Actress Golden Globe (Comedy)]] and [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Academy Award]]. Robbie believed "[Tonya] was always seeking validation...It's tragic that she didn't get it."{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/margot-robbie-i-tonya-depicts-domestic-abuse-a8188831.html|last=Buckley|first=Cara|title=Margot Robbie defends how 'I, Tonya' depicts domestic abuse|date=Feb 1, 2018|newspaper=The Independent|accessdate=Aug 3, 2018}} [[Allison Janney]] played Harding's mother, LaVona, and won the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actress – Motion Picture|Golden Globe]] and [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]]. Regarding Harding's alleged role in Kerrigan's attack, Janney said "I know [Tonya was] complicit, but...I have a lot more empathy for her than I did."{{cite magazine|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/zmy3wa/allison-janney-explains-her-terrifying-terrific-performance-in-i-tonya|title=Allison Janney Explains Her Performance in 'I, Tonya'|first=Lisa |last=Liebman|date=Dec 13, 2017 |magazine=Vice|accessdate=2018-08-08}} Janney also said, "I think LaVona was actually a very smart woman, very articulate...She was not messing around and didn't want [Tonya] distracted...She wanted [Tonya] to know that it was going to be hard work, and knowing her daughter needed to be told she couldn't do it in order to do it was LaVona's way of saying, 'I was there to inspire her.'"{{cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.ca/entry/allison-janney-i-tonya_us_59b57e05e4b0dfaafcf88937|title=Allison Janney's New Favorite Co-Star Is The Bird That Sits On Her Shoulder In 'I, Tonya'|last=Jacobs|first=Matthew|date=2017-09-11|newspaper=HuffPost|accessdate=2018-08-03}} === Academic assessment === Because Harding admitted to obstructing the investigation of Nancy Kerrigan's assault, her name is often first associated with the 1994 scandal. However, numerous academic essays have theorized additional reasons, particularly considering her [[Social class in the United States|national class culture]] and past figure skating membership, for Harding's perceived [[social stigma]]tization.{{cite magazine |last=Marshall |first=Sarah |url=https://believermag.com/remote-control/ |title=Remote Control: Tonya Harding, Nancy Kerrigan, and the Spectacles of Female Power & Pain |magazine=The Believer|date=Jan 2014|accessdate=2017-12-23}} In 1995, the book ''Women on Ice: Feminist Essays on the Tonya Harding/Nancy Kerrigan Spectacle'' was published, containing numerous essays analyzing Harding's public image.{{sfn|Baughman|2013|pages=i–v}} For example, Abigail Feder-Kane wrote that there existed "[[Overdetermination|overdetermined]] [[femininity]] in Ladies' Figure Skating...femininity and [[Women's sports|athleticism]] are mutually exclusive concepts in [[Culture of the United States|American culture]]."{{cite book|last=Oates|first=Thomas P.|editor-last=Burns|editor-first=Gary|year=2016|title=A Companion to Popular Culture (Blackwell Companions in Cultural Studies)|url-access=subscription|pages=275; 282|chapter=Part 5: Pastimes & Practices|department=Sports: Marketing of the Black Style & Containing Gendered Threats|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=P2jWCgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=abigail%20feder-kane|isbn=9781405192057|oclc=959326257|ref=harv|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Ltd|access-date=Aug 15, 2018}} Sam Stoloff believed that, during the scandal, the media placed a greater emphasis on Harding's [[Working class in the United States|class]] rather than her gender (femininity). He noted how she was subjected to a "litany of vaguely [[pejorative]] or mocking expressions" associated with "low class" cultural attributes, sometimes due to Harding's personal interests and hobbies. Stoloff theorized that Harding represented an American social class that required interpretation ("the class Other") as he referenced the [[Anthropology|anthropological]] tone of [[Susan Orlean]]'s 1994 essay "Figures in a Mall," written for ''[[The New Yorker]]''.{{cite book|last=Stoloff|first=Sam|editor1-last=Birrell|editor1-first=Susan|editor2-last=McDonald|editor2-first=Mary G.|year=2000|pages=234–250|title=Reading Sport: Critical Essays on Power and Representation|orig-year=1995|department=Tonya Harding, Nancy Kerrigan, & the Bodily Figuration of Social Class|url-access=subscription|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=U4ukmwWWzgEC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=sam%20stoloff|oclc=43036842|isbn=1555534309|ref=harv|publisher=Northeastern University Press|access-date=Aug 17, 2018}} In academic Sarah Marshall's 2014 essay entitled "Remote Control: Tonya Harding, Nancy Kerrigan, and the Spectacles of Female Power and Pain," she noted the pervasive role of the media in the 1994 scandal, particularly the manner in which Harding's life outside the realm of skating became publicly scrutinized: "Somehow, in the scandal's aftermath, the form of the Tonya-bash was able to alchemize even the most chilling details of Tonya's life into tabloid gold." Marshall also examined the role of Harding's "[[tomboy]]" persona in the context of figure skating. She theorized that Harding was rejected by the figure skating [[ethos]] because she did not conform – as Marshall believed many figure skaters including Nancy Kerrigan did – to appearing as "beautiful without being sexual, strong without being intimidating, and vulnerable without being weak." In Tyler Chase Knowles' 2016 honors thesis entitled "Taking Out the Trash: Middle Class Anxieties and The White Trash Menace," he extrapolated on a quotation made by Emma Gray in her 2014 ''[[HuffPost]]'' article. The quotation explored how Gray believed Harding was labelled "the skating world's perfect villain" due to her appearance, [[Dysfunctional family|broken home]], and [[Poverty in the United States|impoverished background]].{{cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/emma-gray/nancy-kerrigan-tonya-harding-the-price-of-gold_b_4578036.html|department=The Blog|title=What We Missed About The Nancy Kerrigan-Tonya Harding Scandal 20 Years Ago|first=Emma|last=Gray|newspaper=HuffPost|date=Jan 10, 2014|accessdate=Aug 10, 2018}} Knowles theorized that there also existed the [[Sociocultural perspective|socio-cultural]] personified "Defender" who also chose to reject Harding. He defined the "Defender" as a person or persons who sympathize(s) with the [[working poor]], a group including the [[Poor white|white underclass]]. The "Defender" would blame the plight of the poor on [[Economic sociology|societal]] and [[Income inequality in the United States|economic]] factors, yet the "Defender" would continue to reinforce [[Normality (behavior)|conventional values]] such as [[Class stratification|distinguishing the class border]]. Knowles argued that Harding did not belong in the "Defender's" approved category of "poor white" because she did not – in the opinion of the "Defender" – make enough effort, given her figure skating membership, to [[Cultural assimilation|assimilate]] towards [[elite culture]]. The "Defender" wanted Tonya Harding to use her USFSA membership for [[social mobility]], caring little whether she could prove herself to be [[High performance sport|among the best Olympic competitors]].{{cite thesis|last=Knowles|first=Tyler Chase|date=April 2016|publication-place=Connecticut|title=Taking Out the Trash: Middle Class Anxieties and The White Trash Menace|department=The Perfect Woman: A Case Study on Tonya Harding|type=Honors Thesis|chapter=2|publisher=Faculty of Wesleyan University |url=https://wesscholar.wesleyan.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=https://scholar.google.ca/&httpsredir=1&article=2584&context=etd_hon_theses|access-date=Aug 10, 2018}} == References ==
